section.hand:
To my L. T
re
r N
o
16 1591.

addressleaf.section:
1591 16 Nove
m
To my L. Trea
s

page.lettertext:
May it please yo
r
good L. sins I sent you my last
e 11 of this
moneth, there is a German come hither, under coulo
r
of other
buisines: but hath brought certaine letters of credence from
D.
Cassimiere
, of w
ch
one is adressed to
Loeninus
e Chauncelo
r
of
Gelderland;
and one among us in the
Councel of state
, an
other to
Barnevelt,
and a third to
Cant
e bourghmaster of
Amsterdame.
That w
ch
e messenger doth deliver by vertue
of his credence, is the advise of Cassimire to
e forsaid parties,
that in any wise they shoulde persuade w
th
this people, to walke
very warely in returning an answear to
e
Emperors
Ambassado
rs
Not to reject them over peremptorily, nor yet to embrace their
motions, but so to q
a
lifie their answear, as both they may seem
desirous of peace, and yet to trust to no treaty
at is offered by
e
Spaniard. that besides they should urge the treaty betwee
n
her Ma
tie
and this contrey, and
e neere conjunction of their
cause w
t
the present state of
France:
for w
ch
they may request
of
e Emperor to procure a cessation of armes of all handes, and
in all places, and that then they coulde be willing, to come to any
treaty,
at shall tend to a publicke peace. This message of
the Duke is but a preparative to a further letter, w
ch
as
e party
doth report, he is resolved to send hither to
e
G
nra
l states
. For
as it seemeth he is hardly pressed by
e Emperor, to concurre in
the furtherance of this action w
t
him, and
yet
his privat affection
to
e state of these contreis doth move him to be carefull, that
they should not be entrapped. Because his other letter to
e states in g
nra
l is expected every day, there is no answear
yet resolved to be given to this Messenger. Howbeit esteeming
that yo
r
L. would be willingly informed how every thing doth passe
by
e Spaniards procurement, I thought it also requisit to
signifie of this writing of Cassimire hither.
Hage N
o
16 1591.
